results.title: Ron Magliozzi and Jenny He interview: 'Tim Burton: The Exhibition'

video_links.name: Ron Magliozzi and Jenny He interview: 'Tim Burton: The Exhibition'

results.brief_description: Jenny He (Curatorial Assistant, Department of Film) and Ron Magliozzi (Assistant Curator, Department of Film) are co-organizers of the Tim Burton exhibition, from MoMa (The Museum of Modern Art) in New York. Here they are interviewed by Kate Warren, ACMI’s Assistant Curator, about their work on ‘Tim Burton: The Exhibition’. They take us through the process, from inception, through to collaborating with Tim Burton, of Burton’s work and the curatorial process. As well as viewing Tim Burton’s work from an artistic perspective, we also gain insight into the art of the curator and curatorial perspective.

results.title: Our trip to Sydney
results.creator_credit: Bryce O'Neill-Baker, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Bryce O’Neill-Baker tells of the time when he was asked if he wanted to go to Sydney for a short trip. The next day, he joined a bus with family members and others from his community to visit Sydney for the weekend. As well as the normal sightseeing, he also got to experience the NAIDOC festival and warmly shares the effect this time had on his family.

results.title: This is me : foundation for young Australians (July 2009) : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Six young Indigenous Australians look back and reflect on the things, events and people that have inspired, encouraged and, ultimately, shaped them into the youth leaders they have become. While telling different stories, they all have some common themes, of family, connection to their land and culture and spirituality. The stories brim with optimism and uplift and inspire in much the same way that these young people were inspired by the stories of their ancestors.

group_works.title: Spirit, dance and connection = Spirit, dance & connection
group_works.creator_credit: Haryne Uta, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Spirit, dance and connection = Spirit, dance & connection
results.creator_credit: Haryne Uta, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dancing is a way of life, culture and part of our identity. Haryne Uta, a young Torres Strait Islander, started dancing from a very young age. He tells of his journey to not taking it very seriously to realising, under the guidance of his elders, how crucial dancing is to Haryne’s spiritual awakening. The stories of the dance awoke in Haryne a sense of pride and connection to the spiritual world, people and the land.

results.title: A Turning point
results.creator_credit: Noel Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Noel Williamson joined the RAAF because he wanted adventure and he wanted to serve. While his limited education kept him grounded, he speaks fondly of his time in the RAAF, and the opportunities that he grasped with both hands once the war ended.

results.title: The Sleeping dragon
results.creator_credit: Graham Atkinson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The attack on the World Trade Centre in September 2001 resonated with veterans like Graham Atkinson, reminding him of his time in Vietnam during the 1960s and 1970s. Graham tells of how being in the army taught him strength, respect and a sense of dignity for all. Vietnam was a turning point for this Indigenous Australian. He returned highly politicised and railed against violence in his community but left with decades of unresolved memories.

results.title: Bringing his spirit home
results.creator_credit: Dot Peters, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dot Peters’ father was 39 when he joined World War II. He fought in the Middle East and was later captured in Java and sent to a Prisoner of War camp in Japan. He died there, leaving a grieving family wondering what he went through. Simultaneously, they witnessed the injustices inflicted on fellow Indigenous servicemen who had experienced equality overseas, only to find it stripped away on their return. This inspired Dot to dedicate the rest of her life to fighting for Indigenous rights, eventually collaborating with the Shrine of Remembrance to recognise the contribution made by Indigenous people during the war. This fight has helped her to bring her father’s spirit home, to bestow upon his memory a sense of belonging, recognition and honour.

results.title: An Interview with Shirley Cornish
results.brief_description: Shirley Cornish joined the army when a friend, from the store where she worked, said she would. She joined the Australian Womens Army Service and spent most of her life in the service of the army, and tells of her times there and friends made. Army life often bled into Shirley’s personal life, losing a rank in order to spend more time with her mother and, later, joining the Bentleigh War Widows and Widowed Mothers after her husband died. Shirley considers joining this association to be the best thing she ever did and even went on to become its president.

results.title: An Interview with Raymond Jungwirth
results.brief_description: Raymond Jungwirth wanted to fly a spitfire but was convinced to undergo observer training. Initially trained in Canada, Raymond was posted to Europe, where he spent most of World War II. Here he provides a heartfelt account of friends made and lost, the waste of human life and visiting Belsen after the war and the lasting impression that stayed with him even after he returned to Australia.

results.title: An Interview with Brigadier Keith Rossi
results.brief_description: Brigadier Keith Rossi went to join up but needed to lie about his age to do so. He tells of his time in the army with humour, capturing the cameraderie that helped alleviate the horror of war. In his time serving, he went from the Middle East, to New Guinea and, later, Vietnam, from Private to Brigadier.
